videoTitle: Successful DevOps in Web3
videoDescription:
Microsoft is working to collectively empower every person and every organization on the planet to achieve more. Our goal as a company has been to help customers move from on prem to the cloud and now we want to enable our customers to build #Web3 solutions, if they choose. Azure has all of the tools a developer needs, from Azure Static Web Apps, purposely built for your Decentralized app (dApp), to GitHub Actions, and #Azure #DevOps, and VSCode. DevOps best practices are just as important, if not more important in the Web3 world as they are in the Web2 world. In the future, many organizations may build solutions with a combination of Web3 and Web2 working together. Check out this show and go deeper into Web3 with Donovan Brown’s 10-part blog series on how to build a DevOps Pipeline for the Ethereum Blockchain.

videoTitle: Unit Testing for SQL Server Database in DevOps process
videoDescription:
⚡ In this part of the video, we’ll look into how specifically dbForge Unit Test takes part in the development process. Execution of unit tests is one of the most important stages in the database DevOps process because it guarantees that all changes committed by developers to the database project will be verified and and that all functionality will continue working properly after the database is deployed.

Before including unit tests to the DevOps testing process, they first need to be created. You can do it with the help of dbForge Unit Test. This tool also enables you to execute these tests during the CI process.

ℹ️  Including dbForge Unit Test into the DevOps process. The following conditions are necessary for unit test execution:
📍  the tSQLt framework is installed in the database you need to test;
📍 unit tests are present in this database;
You can install the tSQLt framework with the help of the dbForge Unit Test tool for the database on which unit tests will be executed.

dbForge Unit Test provides a convenient interface for creating new tests and modifying existing ones.

Check more useful information: 
🔥 How dbForge Unit Test is involved in the DevOps process here:
https://www.devart.com/dbforge/sql/database-devops/unit-testing.html

🔥 DevOps Automation is a part of SQL Tools:
https://www.devart.com/dbforge/sql/database-devops/download.html

videoTitle: HOW TO CREATE A VARIABLE GROUP ON AZURE DEVOPS
videoDescription:
Variables give you a convenient way to get key bits of data into various parts of the pipeline. The most common use of variables is to define a value that you can then use in your pipeline. All variables are stored as strings and are mutable. The value of a variable can change from run to run or job to job of your pipeline.

OUTLINE

00:00 Go to "Pipelines"
00:04 Click on "Library"
00:08 Click on "Variable Group"
00:14 Define the variable group name
00:28 Add the variables
00:58 Click on "Save"

#azure #devops #variable

videoTitle: QA: What is Quality Assurance #qualityassurance #devops #development  #integrityvision #shorts
videoDescription:
When we talk about Quality Assurance (QA), we should keep in mind different types of things. It's the quality of the documentation, the quality of the code, and of course making sure that the whole testing process is properly taking place. 

Do you consider all the components in your quality assurance? Can you share your answer in the comments? 

To learn more about quality assurance and DevOps, and why it's important for business, watch our full video 'DevOps, QA: Developing & Implementing Complex Turnkey Solutions' here: https://youtu.be/KAyGubuiQpY?si=naiDP85Ft1xp8RLI

videoTitle: How to Create Cron Jobs in Azure DevOps Pipelines  | Automate Your Workflow
videoDescription:
In this video, we'll explore how to schedule cron jobs in Azure DevOps Pipelines using YAML. Whether you're new to Azure DevOps or looking to enhance your CI/CD workflows, this step-by-step guide will help you automate tasks with ease.

**What You'll Learn:**

- Mastering Azure DevOps: Schedule Cron Jobs with YAML
- Step-by-Step Guide to Cron Jobs in Azure DevOps Pipelines
- Enhance Your CI/CD: Setting Up Cron Jobs in Azure DevOps
- Automate Tasks in Azure DevOps Pipelines with Cron Jobs
- How to Get the Required Cron Job Syntax

**Why Watch This Video?**

By the end of this tutorial, you'll understand how to define cron jobs in your Azure DevOps pipelines, ensuring your workflows are efficient and automated. Cron jobs are essential for running scheduled tasks, such as backups, updates, and custom scripts, at specified intervals.

**Key Takeaways:**

- Understanding cron jobs and their importance in automation.
- Setting up your Azure DevOps project for pipeline creation.
- Creating a new pipeline and defining cron jobs in YAML.
- Writing the correct cron job syntax for various scheduling needs.
- Monitoring and managing your cron jobs within Azure DevOps.

videoTitle: هل الـ DevOps engineers مطلوبين في الشركات؟
videoDescription: في الحلقة دي بنناقش كل التفاصيل المهمة عن عالم DevOps. هنتكلم عن اللي كان بيحصل في تطوير البرمجيات قبل ظهور الـ DevOps وإزاي غير المشهد تمامًا. كمان هنوضح الفرق بين DevOps وSRE، وليه بعض الشركات بتفضل تستخدم واحدة عن التانية. لو بتسأل عن فرص الشغل في المجال ده سواء في مصر أو بره، هتعرف حجم الفرص وأهميتها ومتوسط الرواتب اللي ممكن تحققها. الحلقة كمان بتجاوب على سؤال مهم: إيه اللي محتاج تعمله كخريج جديد عشان تبدأ في المجال؟ وهتديك نصايح عملية لكل اللي محتاج تكون مجهزه قبل ما تروح الإنترفيو. متفوتش الفرصة دي لو عايز تبدأ مشوارك في DevOps بخطوات ثابتة وواضحة.

videoTitle: Lumen Tech boosts dev productivity and gains with GitHub Copilot, Azure DevOps, and Visual Studio
videoDescription:
For Lumen Technologies, customer demands catalyzed a need to streamline developer workflows, accelerate problem solving and defect management, and increase developer productivity to build customized solutions quickly and seamlessly. Working with Microsoft, Lumen sponsored a full developer population pilot for GitHub Copilot in India. The nearly 600 engineers gained efficiency, flexibility, and security while delivering great code faster, prompting Lumen to globally expand Copilot to its 2,400 engineers. In addition to significant productivity gains, GitHub Copilot is supporting positive financial gains, with Lumen on track for potential financial benefits between $95 million and $300 million.

videoTitle: How to Migrate TFS to Azure DevOps
videoDescription:
OpsHub Migrator for Microsoft Azure DevOps (OM4ADO) is an enterprise-grade Azure DevOps migration tool developed in partnership with Microsoft. Designed for seamless, no disruption migration, OM4ADO effortlessly transfers work items, test entities, projects and more between all Azure DevOps combinations with no downtime.

OM4ADO allows you to move data across organizations and collections, and customize the migration process to meet your needs. The delta sync feature ensures a smooth cutover by allowing for incremental updates and synchronization between source and target systems. This eliminates the need for source system downtime, as you can continue using it while the target system is validated. 

Watch how OM4ADO can move projects between the source and the target in this TFS to Azure DevOps (VSTS) migration in five simple steps.

videoTitle: DevOps vs Platform Engineering: Platform Engineering replaced DevOps
videoDescription:
🚀 Build Your Own Platform & Launch Your Products! 🚀

Join the Out of DevOps community 👉 https://lab.outofdevops.com and get the resources you need to create your personal platform!

Want 1:1 guidance? Book a call with me here 👉 https://stan.store/outofdevops Today we'll be discussing the differences between DevOps and platform engineering. 

There are various definitions for DevOps and Platform Engineering. This video will be mainly based on my experiences as software engineer working in the DevOps/platform engineering space for the past few years.

DevOps is a set of practices that aims to bridge the gap between development (dev) and operations (ops) teams. The goal is to improve collaboration, and not have two silos with the dev team sitting on one side and the ops team sitting on the other.

So I have always seen devops as a mindset and just another fancy way of saying software engineer.
For me the goal has always been to build cross-functional teams to reduce dependencies in organisations.
This concept has been popularised by the AWS mantra "You build it you run it" where you have the need for teams with T shaped or even better V shaped engineers.

The DevOps approach works well but when you start having several teams each implementing different ways of going to production you are solving the same problem multiple times.
Also these solutions need to be maintained and it's a full time job.

Platform engineering focuses on building and maintaining the infrastructure and the systems that supports applications and services. 
Their goal is to support developers in the organisation by creating and maintaining the platform. Developers are the consumers and customers of the platform (Product).

IDP stands for internal developer platform. And it's the way developer interface with the toolchain in their organisation.
The goal is to have teams using a self-service portal to support their application throughout the SDLC

#devops #platformengineering

videoTitle: Django Simple Deploy and other DevOps Things - Talk Python to Me Ep. 500
videoDescription:
We’re sitting down with Eric Matthes, the educator, author, and developer behind Django Simple Deploy. If you’ve ever struggled with taking that final step of getting your Django app onto a live server (without spending days wrestling with DevOps complexities), then give Django Simple Deploy a look. Eric shares how Django Simple Deploy automates away the boilerplate parts of deployment, so you can focus on building features instead of deciphering endless configs. videoTitle: Cracking the DevOps Code: Courses & Certifications for Success
videoDescription:
Take the courses mentioned here, get certifications and do not forget to add these using our AI-Powered Resume Builder (https://pro.kudoswall.com)
Certifications for Employed DevOps Professionals:
AWS Certified DevOps Engineer: This certification from Amazon Web Services (AWS) validates your expertise in deploying, operating, and managing applications on the AWS platform.
Azure DevOps Engineer: Offered by Microsoft, this certification demonstrates your skills in designing and implementing DevOps practices using Azure technologies.
Google Cloud Professional DevOps Engineer: This certification focuses on designing, developing, and managing DevOps practices on the Google Cloud Platform.
Certified Kubernetes Administrator (CKA): Certified by the Cloud Native Computing Foundation (CNCF), CKA validates your Kubernetes skills, which are crucial for container orchestration.
Certified Jenkins Engineer: Offered by CloudBees, this certification recognizes your proficiency in using Jenkins for continuous integration and continuous delivery (CI/CD) pipelines.
Red Hat Certified Engineer in DevOps: This certification from Red Hat validates your skills in using Red Hat technologies for automating, managing, and optimizing DevOps processes.

Courses for Aspiring DevOps Engineers:
Introduction to DevOps Practices: Online platforms like Coursera, edX, and Udemy offer various introductory courses that cover the fundamental concepts and practices of DevOps.
Docker and Kubernetes Courses: Understanding containerization and orchestration tools like Docker and Kubernetes is essential. There are numerous courses available for beginners and advanced users.
Cloud Platform Courses (AWS, Azure, GCP): Learning the basics of cloud platforms and their DevOps-related services is crucial. Many platforms offer free and paid courses for beginners.
CI/CD Pipeline Courses: Courses on continuous integration and continuous delivery tools like Jenkins, GitLab CI/CD, and CircleCI are essential for automating software delivery.
Infrastructure as Code (IaC) Courses: Learning tools like Terraform and Ansible for automating infrastructure deployment is key for DevOps engineers.
Monitoring and Logging Courses: Understanding tools like Prometheus, Grafana, and ELK Stack (Elasticsearch, Logstash, Kibana) for monitoring and logging is vital.
Scripting and Programming Courses: Proficiency in scripting languages like Python and programming languages like Java can enhance your DevOps skills.
Security and Compliance Courses: DevOps engineers should also be well-versed in security practices. Courses on DevSecOps and security automation can be beneficial.
#DevOpsIndia #Certifications #Courses #TechSkills #CareerGrowth #Cloud #Automation

videoTitle: Matthew Skelton - DevOps Topologies 10 years on: what have we learned about silos, collaboration...
videoDescription:
In this talk, Matthew Skelton - CEO at Conflux and co-author of the book Team Topologies - explores the key learnings from 10 years of Team Topologies and State of DevOps Reports and outlines key steps that organizations can take to improve IT delivery performance:

Organize for flow
Address team cognitive load
Estimate the cost of “tangled software”
Use the Accelerate metrics and community techniques to find good boundaries for flow
Develop secure foundations in social and technical practices that support fast flow
Take a realistic view about the nature and scale of change needed
By combining learnings from State of DevOps Reports and Team Topologies together with principles championed by the DevOps community, organizations can navigate a route to business agility via a fast flow operating model.

videoTitle: What is Secure DevOps?
videoDescription:
It’s surprisingly easy for hackers to impersonate authorized users of your corporate Git environment. Why? Because your developers can access it using their personal accounts, which are not tied to a corporate identity. That makes it difficult for IT to control access. And because contributors can sign the author field of a commit with anything they like, IT can’t track who is really authoring these commits.

Just as bad, contributors are committing code on unauthorized machines, often without even logging into the Git web service, evading all access controls.

This leaves your software components vulnerable to unauthorized access and tampering, which can lead to malicious code getting distributed to all of your clients.

With Secure DevOps by Beyond Identity, you can ensure that only your developers check in code to your repo. And that all commits came from an authorized user and device. All without impacting software velocity.
channelDescription:
Beyond Identity is the only IAM platform architected to stop unauthorized access. Our mission is to protect the livelihood of our customers, freeing them to focus on what matters. 

Every other IAM platform was built to drive productivity, making security an afterthought and providing a highway for bad actors to exploit. Beyond Identity is the only secure-by-design IAM platform foundationally built to ensure only trusted users and secure devices can ever gain and maintain access.

videoTitle: Azure DevOps Migration Tool for VSTS Migration
videoDescription:
OpsHub Migrator for Microsoft Azure DevOps (OM4ADO), previously known as OADOM and OVSMU, is an enterprise–grade Azure DevOps migration tool designed for zero downtime and no disruption Azure DevOps migration. OM4ADO simplifies consolidation efforts across various Azure DevOps organizations, eliminating challenges such as high maintenance costs, reduced productivity, and insufficient reporting. It seamlessly migrates work items, test entities and more enhancing business agility.   

Developed in collaboration with Microsoft, OM4ADO helps in comprehensive transfer of data with full context within the Microsoft landscape whether it is a TFS to Azure DevOps (VSTS) migration or an Azure DevOps to Azure DevOps migration or any other combination of the two instances.   

OM4ADO also allows you to efficiently transfer data between organizations and collections. The delta sync feature enables incremental updates and data sync between source and target, eliminating source system downtime and allowing uninterrupted use of the source system during target system validation.  

Watch this video to learn how OM4ADO migrates data from VSTS to VSTS hassle-free!  

For more information on Azure DevOps Migrations with OM4ADO, visit: https://www.opshub.com/products/opshub-azure-devops-migrator/

videoDescription: Continuous Integration and Continuous Delivery (CICD) is a transformative technology streamlining development productivity. By hosting code on GitHub and configuring details with CICD providers like Azure, Jenkins, AWS, or Heroku, developers automate the deployment process. Pushing code changes triggers automatic deployments to specified endpoints, significantly enhancing the development cycle. videoTitle: So you want to learn DevOps? Watch this first...
videoDescription:
🚀 Build Your Own Platform & Launch Your Products! 🚀

Join the Out of DevOps community 👉 https://lab.outofdevops.com and get the resources you need to create your personal platform!

Want 1:1 guidance? Book a call with me here 👉 https://stan.store/outofdevops In this video, I am going to share my personal journey from application development to DevOps engineering and provide tips on how you can make the transition too. I started as a software engineer, coding applications, but soon realised there was more to it than just writing code. This curiosity led me to explore the DevOps space.

To break down the vast field of DevOps, focus on learning the software development lifecycle and understanding the role of a platform team working in the DevOps space. Grasping essential concepts like continuous integration (CI), automating steps from the developer machine to production, ensuring application reliability and security, and keeping up with new tools will help you excel in this field.

Remember, you'll never be done learning in the DevOps space, as there's always something new to master. Companies use different tools, so don't worry about knowing everything. What truly matters is your motivation and willingness to learn. Embrace the process of constant growth and pushing yourself out of your comfort zone.

If you're ready for the challenge, you've made the right decision to enter the DevOps space. But if not, reconsider your choices, as building and updating your skills is an ongoing process in this field. Be sure to check out my other videos on DevOps and platform engineering, and leave any questions you have in the comments below. See you in the next one!

videoTitle: Master DevOps: The Ultimate DevOps Learning Path with Pulumi
videoDescription:
Mastering DevOps tools doesn't have to be overwhelming. We've all struggled with confusing tutorials and documentation that leaves us more puzzled than prepared. Today, we're breaking down an effective approach to learning Pulumi, combining practical workshop experience with research-backed learning principles that will help you succeed. 

Join Alexandre Nédélec, a .NET developer turned DevOps enthusiast, as he shares his comprehensive learning roadmap for Pulumi. We'll explore how to transform traditional infrastructure management into code while avoiding common learning pitfalls. Whether you're new to infrastructure as code or looking to level up your skills, you'll discover actionable strategies to make your learning journey more effective.

Key topics covered:
- Research-backed learning principles for technical skills
- Essential Pulumi concepts: projects, stacks, and state management
- Practical approaches to secrets handling and provider selection
- Tips for effective environment setup and configuration
- Strategies for working with existing infrastructure

Want to get started right? Here are five key principles for effective learning:
1. Set up your environment properly before diving in
2. Choose a motivating personal project
3. Follow established learning paths
4. Learn with others through pair programming
5. Focus on mastering fundamentals before advancing

00:57 - Meet Alexander: A DevOps Enthusiast

In this episode, I sit down with Yevgeniy Brikman, co-founder of Gruntwork and author of “Terraform: Up & Running,” to discuss his upcoming book, “The Fundamentals of DevOps and Software Delivery.”

Yevgeniy Brikman’s Bio
Yevgeniy (Jim) Brikman loves programming, writing, speaking, traveling, and lifting heavy things. He does not love talking about himself in the 3rd person. He is the co-founder of Gruntwork, a company that offers products & services for setting up world-class DevOps Foundations. He’s also the author of three books published by O’Reilly Media: Fundamentals of DevOps and Software Delivery, Terraform: Up & Running, and Hello, Startup. Previously, he spent more than a decade building infrastructure and products that served hundreds of millions of users while working as a software engineer at LinkedIn, TripAdvisor, Cisco Systems, and Thomson Financial.

videoTitle: What's the goal of Platform Engineering? #shorts #devops #platformengineering
videoDescription:
Watch the full video: https://youtu.be/JAblex0uS4k

What’s the goal of Platform Engineering? Platform Engineering focusses on the building the infrastructure and the systems that are needed for running your applications and supporting your application throughout the software life cycle. So,  the goal  is to support the developers in the organisation and treat them as customers. That’s why we have in platform engineering the concept of IDP Internal developer platform.
 
So, this platform is treated as an actual product and the customers of the product are the developers.
What is the role of the IDP?
It is to create a thin layer on top of the toolchain that is used inside the organisation to standardise the processes and help developers to have one way to deploy into production

videoTitle: #Day5 of #100DaysOfDevOps: Essentials of Networking for DevOps
videoDescription:
#DevOps #NetworkingEssentials #LinuxCommands #OSIModel #CloudComputing #DevOpsSkills #TechFundamentals #NetworkingBasics #NetworkingForDevOps #DevOpsJourney #100daysofdevops 

🚀 Unlocking Networking Essentials for DevOps 🚀

In today’s video, we’re diving into one of the most crucial areas for any DevOps professional—Networking! 🌐 Understanding networking basics is key for managing cloud resources, troubleshooting connectivity, and ensuring smooth deployments.

In this video, we cover:

📚 Networking Basics & OSI Model
Explore the OSI Model and understand how each layer functions.

🛠️ Essential Linux Commands for Networking
Boost your efficiency in networking with must-know commands:

ifconfig/ip: View and manage network interfaces.
ping: Check connectivity to other hosts.
traceroute: Trace packet paths to their destinations.
netstat/ss: Inspect active connections and listening ports.
nslookup/dig: Retrieve DNS information.
curl/wget: Make HTTP requests and download files.
tcpdump: Capture and analyze network packets.
nc (Netcat): A versatile tool for reading and writing data across networks.
Mastering these commands and concepts will empower you to troubleshoot, configure, and optimize network settings like a pro.

Tune in to gain valuable insights and practical skills essential for any DevOps journey! 🚀

videoTitle: What is Git? How would you define Git? || #GitHub #GitLab #BitBucket #DevOps #Git #Python #Java
videoDescription:
What is Git?

How would you define Git?

Well, Git is a distributed version control system, which means two things:

1. It's distributed so people around the world can share code
2. It does version control

So, with version control, you can take snapshots of the state of your current code and maintain a history.

Branching is really the third thing. Git branches allow developers to do isolated development and take chances without messing up the main branch.

So when someone asks me 'What is Git?', that is how I typically respond.

videoTitle: Bringing Security & DevOps Together | Making DevSecOps Easy
videoDescription:
DevOps engineers are increasingly becoming the ones that are responsible for maintaining the security of their infrastructure. And these environments are becoming more complex to manage.

Every technology needs a special hardening, a special secure configuration, and not every DevOps person has the special knowledge about the security configuration at every layer.

We want to give you answers to fix these problems easily and with confidence.

Mondoo is full stack security designed for DevOps teams. It fits into your workflow so you can test the infrastructure you're building from local development through your pipeline and all the way through into your runtime environments.

We give you a comprehensive view into your infrastructure no matter which layer you’re looking at. We help you understand what you have and what needs to be improved.
channelDescription: The Mondoo unified security platform finds and prioritizes vulnerabilities and misconfigurations that pose the highest risk to your business. Mondoo's security data fabric analyzes the threat and exposure of every finding within the unique context of your infrastructure. Instead of a flood of irrelevant security alerts, Mondoo shows you how you can make an immediate and significant impact on your security posture.

videoTitle: DevOps 4 Devs-Introduction: Basic DevOps Tools & Version Control | git
videoDescription:
In this series we will learn the concepts of DevOps from a perspective of developers. How can these concepts help us be better developers and managers in our day to day jobs. In a startup you might need to fill the shoes of a DevOps, in a big company you might need to communicate with a DevOps team that has wildly different ideas.

We will gain a different perspective and understanding of the entire process by leaving our comfort zone and focusing on the wider picture. We will learn about different disciplines such as platform engineering and so much more.

In the first installment we discuss version control. As developers, we see it as a tool to collaborate and save our code. To track our mistakes and changes. In this video we learn why it's a crucial nexus point with the DevOps team and how we can work better to enable that.

videoDescription:
A DevOps engineer serves as a pivotal link between development and operations teams, fostering seamless collaboration and communication to optimize the software delivery lifecycle.

At the core of a DevOps engineer's role is the establishment and maintenance of CI/CD pipelines, ensuring the continuous integration and deployment of software updates. This accelerates the release of new features and fixes, ultimately reducing the time required for delivering impactful changes.

In summary, the collaborative efforts and automation prowess of a DevOps engineer create an environment conducive to rapid and high-quality software delivery, empowering organizations to stay competitive in the dynamic landscape of software development.

videoTitle: Manage & Secure Kubernetes Cluster Policies via OPA Gatekeeper. #opa #devops #gatekeeper
videoDescription:
Manage & Secure Kubernetes Cluster Policies via OPA Gatekeeper. #opa #devops #gatekeepers 

Timestamps:

Theory/Concepts : 00:00
Hands on/Practical : 09:00

github repo : https://github.com/RohanRusta21/opa-gatekeeper.git

Concepts :

OPA Gatekeeper: Policy and Governance for Kubernetes

What is OPA:

The Open Policy Agent (OPA) is an open-source, general-purpose policy engine that unifies policy enforcement across the stack. OPA provides a high-level declarative language that lets us specify policies as code and simple APIs to offload policy decision-making from our software. We can use OPA to enforce policies in microservices, Kubernetes, CI/CD pipelines, API gateways, and more. 
In kubernetes, OPA uses admission controllers.

What is OPA Gatekeeper?

OPA Gatekeeper is a specialized project providing first-class integration between OPA and Kubernetes.
OPA Gatekeeper adds the following on top of plain OPA:
● An extensible, parameterized policy library.
● Native Kubernetes CRDs for instantiating the policy library (aka “constraints”).
● Native Kubernetes CRDs for extending the policy library (aka “constraint templates”).
● Audit functionality.

Why you need Gatekeeper?

As a Platform DevOps engineer managing multiple Kubernetes clusters for various projects, you face challenges when users deploy applications without adhering to best practices. Key issues include:
  1.     Lack of ownership unless users apply labels themselves.
  2.     No resource limits, leading to high costs.
  3.     Untrusted images impacting other applications.
  4.     Security and best practice violations across clusters.

To address these, we need governance to enforce limits and rules via policies. OPA Gatekeeper can be configured to implement these policies, ensuring best practices are followed.

videoTitle: Real world DevOps project from start to finish - WireGuard VPN Part 1
videoDescription:
CHECK OUT MY DEVOPS COURSE WITH 85% OFF COUPON AT https://sre.rs

Hello everyone,


I've made a DevOps course covering a lot of different technologies and applications,
aimed at startups, small companies and individuals who want to self-host
their infrastructure.

This video shows the first part of setting up WireGuard VPN.

TL;DR:
Course page: https://www.udemy.com/course/real-world-devops-project-from-start-to-finish/?referralCode=9AC467077593D22878A2
Discount coupon is available at https://sre.rs

Details:
To get this out of the way - this course doesn't cover Kubernetes or similar -
I'm of the opinion that for startups, small companies, and especially individuals,
you probably don't need Kubernetes. Unless you have a whole DevOps team,
it usually brings more problems than benefits, and unnecessary infrastructure bills
buried a lot of startups before they got anywhere.

As for prerequisites, you can't be a complete beginner in the world of computers.
If you've never even heard of Docker, if you don't know at least something about DNS,
or if you don't have any experience with Linux, this course is probably not for you.
That being said, I do explain the basics too, but probably not in enough detail
for a complete beginner.

I encourage you to watch "free preview" videos to get the sense of what
will be covered, but here's the gist:

The goal of the course is to create an easily deployable and reproducible server
which will have "everything" a startup or a small company will need - VPN, mail, Git,
CI/CD, messaging, hosting websites and services, sharing files, calendar, etc.
It can also be useful to individuals who want to self-host all of those - I ditched Google 99.9%
and other than that being a good feeling, I'm not worried that some AI bug will lock my account
with no one to talk to about resolving the issue.

Considering that it covers a wide variety of topics, it doesn't go in depth in any of those.
Think of it as going down a highway towards the end destination, but on the way there I show you
all the junctions where I think it's useful to do more research on the subject.

We'll deploy services inside Docker and LXC (Linux Containers). Those will include
a mail server (iRedMail), Zulip (Slack and Microsoft Teams alternative), GitLab (with GitLab Runner and CI/CD),
Nextcloud (file sharing, calendar, contacts, etc.), checkmk (monitoring solution), Pi-hole (ad blocking on DNS level),
Traefik with Docker and file providers (a single HTTP/S entry point with automatic routing and TLS certificates).

We'll set up WireGuard, a modern and fast VPN solution for secure access to VPS' internal network,
and I'll also show you how to get a wildcard TLS certificate with certbot and DNS provider.

To wrap it all up, we'll write a simple Python application that will compare a list of the desired backups
with the list of finished backups, and send a result to a Zulip stream.
We'll write the application, do a 'git push' to GitLab which will trigger a CI/CD pipeline
that will build a Docker image, push it to a private registry, and then,
with the help of the GitLab runner, run it on the VPS and post a result to a Zulip stream with a webhook.


If you apply the coupon, I'd appreciate if you leave your feedback on Udemy
after you're done and spread the word about the course. It would mean a lot.


I hope that you find it useful.


Happy learning,
Predrag

videoTitle: 8 DevOps Best Practices You MUST KNOW in 2024 | Essential DevOps Best Practices 2024
videoDescription:
In this comprehensive video, we will cover various key aspects of DevOps best practices. We'll start with an insightful introduction, providing you with a solid foundation of understanding DevOps and its significance in the modern IT landscape. Then, we'll explore the criticality of cultural change and how it plays a pivotal role in fostering a collaborative and innovation-driven work environment.

Next, we'll dive into version control and trunk-based development, showcasing how these practices streamline code management and facilitate seamless collaboration among developers. Automation will also take center stage, as we discuss the benefits of automating repetitive tasks, enabling faster deployment and reducing manual errors.

Moving forward, we'll shed light on continuous integration and continuous delivery, two pivotal practices that ensure frequent code integration and deployment. Monitoring and feedback will be explored as well, emphasizing the vital role of real-time feedback loops and continuous monitoring in maintaining software quality and performance.

Moreover, we'll delve into the realm of DevSecOps, highlighting the importance of integrating security into every stage of the development process. Building secure applications is paramount in an age where cyber threats are constantly evolving.

We'll also touch upon the significance of identical and reproducible environments, discussing how environment consistency leads to smoother deployments and more reliable software. Lastly, we'll emphasize the significance of documentation, highlighting how well-documented procedures and code enable efficient collaboration and knowledge sharing.

Join us on this insightful journey as we unpack the essential DevOps best practices for 2023. Make sure to subscribe to our channel and hit the notification bell to stay updated with the latest trends and advancements in the world of DevOps!

This talk is designed to equip tech professionals with the knowledge to integrate eco-conscious decisions into their daily work, ultimately contributing to a healthier planet. The goal is for the audience to learn how their role in technology can drive positive environmental change, ensuring a greener future through thoughtful innovation and operations.

videoTitle: DevOps in Your Shopping Cart with Stephan Rupp, Pentland Firth WOC005 #devops #eshopping #automation
videoDescription:
Pentland Firth's smart shopping solution EASY Shopper is currently being deployed in the shopping carts of a major German supermarket chain. Right now, it’s been rolled out in Germany. And yay! We have Stephan Rupp from Pentland Firth as our guest.

Stephan, as the Team Lead for his operations team, describes to our host Christian Steinberger the exciting development journey from separate operations and development teams and manual server provisioning to a modern organization embracing automation.

From the start, Pentland Firth aimed to handle their solution with a small team, making Stephan and his team true pioneers in automation over the past eight years. Stephan discusses the challenges and successes they faced culturally, entrepreneurially, organizationally, and in sales. On the technical side, Stephan talks about their tool stack – from Ansible and Kubernetes to Terraform.

Stephan's conclusion: His team lives DevOps and has internalized the values and culture that DevOps demands from us.

Listen in! And hey, you know we’re thrilled about your subscriptions, comments, and likes

SHOWNOTES
Theory of Constraint: https://de.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Theory_of_Constraints
"The Phoenix Project": https://itrevolution.com/product/the-phoenix-project/

channelDescription:
WALLS OF CONFUSION entstehen im IT-Alltag aufgrund unterschiedlicher Perspektiven von Software-Entwicklung (Dev) und IT-Betrieb (Ops). Der Ansatz DevOps löst die klassisch zutagetretenden Probleme in der Zusammenarbeit, strafft die Time-to-Market und enabelt unternehmerische Effizienz.

Herzlich willkommen auf der Ops-Seite der Wall of Confusion! Unser Job ist es, die Software von Entwicklerteams in einen einsatzfähigen Zustand zu bringen und somit ihren Erfolg zu sichern. Dafür bauen wir zum Beispiel Pipelines durch die Wall oder schaffen Verbindungen oder Automatismen hinüber zur Entwicklerseite. Unser aller Ziel sind cloud-native bzw. microservices-basierte Architekturen in modernen Multicloud-Umgebungen.

Hier erzählen wir euch vom Ops-Alltag, von der Zusammenarbeit mit Entwicklerteams, generell über unsere Branche, über Lösungen, über Organisation, über Menschen, Methoden und Tools. Abonniert unseren Kanal, aktiviert die Glocke und diskutiert mit uns.

videoTitle: DevOps Project #1 (Part 1): Multi-Cloud Automation - Project Overview
videoDescription:

videoTitle: Practical DevOps: Continuous Delivery vs Continuous Deployment
videoDescription:
Continuous integration, deployment, and delivery are like vectors with the same direction but different magnitudes. Their goal is the same: to make our software development and release process faster and more robust.

The key difference between the three is in the scope of automation applied. What confuses people new to the field is that they are not mutually exclusive, but include each other, like Russian dolls.

⏰ Timestamps
0:00 Continuous Delivery vs Continuous Deployment
2:18 Continuous Delivery benefits
3:19 The inputs and outputs of Continuous Delivery
5:14 Benefits of Continuous Deployment
6:24 Key takeaways
7:05 Conclusion

videoTitle: One DevOps does not git all by Allen Geer - NZ Tech Rally 2023
videoDescription:
Recorded at NZ Tech Rally conference, on 7th July 2023.

Transcript on NZ Tech Rally website: https://nztechrally.nz/speakers/allen-geer/?utm_campaign=nztr2023content&utm_source=youtube&utm_medium=social&utm_content=transcript

New Zealand organisations use DevOps practices and culture in different ways.

In this talk, we will investigate how different sizes and scale organisations are using DevOps technical and cultural practices to drive different outcomes. 

We will investigate how in large enterprises, DevOps is more about assurance and safety, whereas, in resource-constrained startups, DevOps is about speed and learning.

00:00 Prae introduces Allen
01:14 Allen introduces his talk
03:37 Differences in scale between New Zealand and USA 
06:30 What is DevOps?
09:28 Story 1 - Where DevOps is a bad word
12:24 Story 2 - DevOps for feedback
14:30 Story 3 - Big solutions for small problems; over-engineering solutions
20:57 Story 4 - Technology systems are actually techno-social systems
22:47 Safety is an emergent property of DevOps
25:52 Audience question: Why are you leaving NZ?
27:02 Audience question: DevOps is a dirty word. What did it take to change that mindset?

About the speaker:

For the last 6 years Allen Geer has been helping New Zealand organisations modernise business processes and applications leveraging DevOps practices as well as public cloud platforms.

Prior to moving to New Zealand, Allen worked as a consultant and software engineer at several Fortune 500 enterprises across the United States.

Allen has been involved with startups, multinational banks, and governments and has seen DevOps and software development practices implemented to varying degrees at many different scales.

videoTitle: DevOps at Scale | GitKon 2022 | Andrew Pankevicius, Atlassian
videoDescription:
DevOps at Scale: What it Really Looks Like to Scale Your Product Org from 1 to 100 People

DevOps at scale can be tricky, especially if you’re growing your team. Get best practices from Andrew Pankevicius, senior product manager for Jira DevOps at Atlassian. 

As organizations scale, teams quickly learn that it’s not just about hiring. It’s also about how your team’s tools and internal development practices pivot, scale and grow to meet the increasing needs of your organization. 

Andrew Pankevicius, senior product manager for Jira DevOps at Atlassian, walks through the critical milestones of growth, from DevSecOps as a foundational concept on day one, to cross-functional release orchestration and managing your DevOps toolchain while scaling your development team.

videoTitle: Boosting DevOps Efficiency with AI Tools: A Guide to ChatGPT, Claude, Copilot, and More
videoDescription:
Boosting DevOps efficiency with AI tools like ChatGPT, Claude, and Copilot is transforming modern workflows. 

My LinkedIn https://www.linkedin.com/in/roman-burdiuzha/
Cloud Architect | Co-Founder & CTO at  https://gartsolutions.com/

In this video, we delve into how DevOps engineers can leverage AI-powered tools to automate routine tasks, streamline code generation, and enhance project management. From using ChatGPT for quick brainstorming to Claude’s structured file organization, each tool serves a unique purpose. Copilot, integrated into Visual Studio, offers code generation and real-time explanations to improve coding speed and understanding. 

For UI prototyping, Vercel's VZero simplifies the creation of frontend designs, making it accessible to engineers without a UI background. Discover how these tools can accelerate your DevOps projects and see how AI assistants are reshaping the industry. Whether you're looking to save time on deployments or improve your code quality, this guide offers actionable insights to integrate AI into your workflow.

videoTitle: Stop using Read-Host and do this instead #powershell  #devops  #scripting
videoDescription:
Stop using Read-Host and do this instead:

Read-Host has limitations. 

- You cannot pass information to it 
- You cannot validate what the user provided
- It always stops the script

There is a better way - use parameters instead.

- Control the type of input
- Make it mandatory or optional
- Pass argument from the command line
- or prompt the user to provide an argument, when required and not passed

In this short video, I'll show you how to implement simple parameters and how to use them.

Would you like to learn more about the parameters?

videoTitle: What is CICD? #continuousdeployment #continuousintegration #devops #coding #infrastructureascode
videoDescription:
**Description for YouTube Shorts:**

Continuous Integration and Continuous Delivery (CI/CD) are essential practices in modern DevOps workflows. CI ensures code changes are automatically tested and integrated into the main branch, while CD automates the deployment process, delivering updates to users quickly and efficiently. Streamline your development process with CI/CD!

videoTitle: "MLOps + DevOps + Kubernetes = ❤️" By Annie Talvasto
videoDescription:
Combining the power of DevOps, Kubernetes and MLOps brings scalability, reliability, and reproducibility to AI and ML workflows. In this session, we will explore how Kubernetes enables the orchestration of distributed AI training and inference pipelines, while MLOps practices ensure efficient model development, deployment, and monitoring. Join Annie to discover how this combination empowers organizations to unlock the full potential of generative AI while achieving seamless scalability and operational excellence.

Annie Talvasto is an award-winning international technology speaker and leader. She has spoken at over 60 technology conferences worldwide, including KubeCon + CloudNativeCon and Microsoft Build & Ignite. She has been recognized with the CNCF Ambassador, Azure & AI Platform MVP awards. Annie is the creator of TechCraft Show, where she and her guests talk tech while playing Minecraft (potentially) badly. She has co-organized the Kubernetes & CNCF Finland meetup since 2017. In the past, she has also served as a track chair for KubeCon + CloudNativeCon, Program Chair for Secure AI Summit (powered by Cloud Native) and has been hosting Cloud Native Live, a weekly livestream by CNCF, since 2021.

videoTitle: Backup Dataverse Development Environment | PowerApps & Azure DevOps
videoDescription:
Have you ever lost progress in your Dataverse development environment and wished you had a backup? In this video, I'll guide you through the process of setting up a DevOps pipeline in Azure DevOps to automate backups of your Dataverse environment. This pipeline will help you keep a historical record of your work, saving you time and frustration in case something goes wrong.

The accompanying blog post - https://techtweedie.github.io/posts/backup-dataverse-development-environment/

What You’ll Learn:
==============
- Prerequisites for setting up a backup pipeline in Azure DevOps
- Step-by-step guide to creating your first pipeline
- How to export, manage, and unpack solutions from Dataverse
- Troubleshooting common issues during the pipeline setup
- Full YAML pipeline script for easy implementation

Whether you're a seasoned developer or just getting started with Power Platform DevOps, this tutorial will equip you with the tools you need to protect your development environment.

In the Next Video:
==============
I’ll be expanding on this pipeline, adding features like Power Pages Portal integration, exploring XML changes, utilizing environment variables, and auto-generating wiki articles based on your solution components.

Have Questions? 
=============
Drop them in the comments below or on the YouTube video, and I'll be happy to dive deeper into any of the steps.

videoTitle: Automating license enforcement in your CI/CD pipeline and trends in DevOps with Eli Birger
videoDescription:
Eli's talk at DevOpsDays Raleigh focused on automating license checks in CI/CD pipelines. Of course, the topic of open source licenses is fascinating to the All Things Open community and we wanted to learn more. During this interview, we talked with Eli about the importance of open source licensing, in particular, how they are automating license enforcement. Then we discussed some trends in DevOps from the perspective of a former DevOps engineer and manager.

Registration for All Things Open 2024 is now open. Register now to save your spot: https://allthingsopen.org/ato-registration-now-open

0:00 - Introduction
0:08 - Welcome Eli Birger
0:40 - Tell us about yourself
2:10 - Can you share a few key takeaways that you shared with the audience here? 
3:28 - Why are open source licenses important?
4:16 - What's happening in DevOps, a topic, a trend, a debate, that people should be aware of?
5:09 - What's one piece of advice that you want to share with the All Things Open community?

Key takeaways:
* We publicly share  the CI/CD enforcement we built for different types of licenses
* The topic of open source licenses is very complex and very boring
* The volume of licenses complicates the space
* Be aware of "blind spots" in your processes and methodology
* Do not take things for granted and challenge everything
* Invest at least one hour a day for learning and challenging things

###
About Eli Birger 
Eli is a passionate technologist with a background in telecom, cyber, and storage. He has over six years of experience as a DevOps Manager, where he specialized in building large-scale SaaS systems based on Kubernetes. As the CTO at PerfectScales, his current focus is on building solutions that solve the pains of operating highly-disturbed Kubernetes systems, keeping them running both efficiently and resiliently.

About All Things Open
All Things Open is a universe of open source events and platforms designed to educate and connect technologists around the world. It includes the All Things Open conference, the largest open source / tech / web event on the U.S. East Coast, meetups in the Research Triangle Park (RTP) of NC, South Carolina, and New York City, and a YouTube channel with more than 1,000 free recordings. See everything we do at https://allthingsopen.org.

Join our meetups:
* New York City meetup: https://www.meetup.com/Open-Source-NYC/
* South Carolina meetup: https://www.meetup.com/open-source-south-carolina/
* Research Triangle Park, NC meetup: https://www.meetup.com/all-things-open-rtp-meetup/

Follow All Things Open:
* YouTube: https://www.youtube.com/c/AllThingsOpen/videos
* LinkedIn: https://www.linkedin.com/company/all-things-open
* Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/allthingsopen/
* Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/AllThingsOpen/
* Twitter: https://twitter.com/AllThingsOpen

videoDescription:
Lightning talk at The DEVOPS Conference - Global 2023: LIGHTNING TALK: DEVOPS FOR JAVA DEVELOPERS

In recent years, how we approach development has dramatically changed with the rise of DevOps, Cloud Computing, and Container technologies. Many stakeholders at our organizations are ecstatic about Shift Left, DevSecOps and VSM, but how are we as Java developers embracing this new cultural shift? In this session we explore the most common Critical Challenges to Adopt DevOps Culture in Software Organizations, best practices and some excellent news with success stories. #Java #DevOps #DevOpsForJavaDevelopers #DevOps #TheDEVOPSConference

Speaker: Ixchel Ruiz has developed software applications and tools since 2000. Her research interests include Java, dynamic languages, client-side technologies, DevSecOps, and testing. videoTitle: Top 5 IT Domains in 2025|AI|ML|Cybersecurity|Cloud|DevOps|Data|FullStack Development
videoDescription:
On this channel, we will dive deep into the fascinating worlds of DevOps and Cloud. Together, we will explore the powerful fusion of development and operations, enabling organizations to deliver software faster, more reliably, and at scale. I will share my knowledge, insights, and practical experiences to help you navigate the ever-evolving landscape of DevOps and Cloud.

1. Artificial Intelligence (AI) & Machine Learning

 Technologies/Skills to Learn:
  Python, TensorFlow, PyTorch
  OpenAI API, LangChain, Hugging Face
  Scikit-learn, Pandas, NumPy
  MLflow, Weights & Biases (MLOps)
  Prompt Engineering (for GenAI)
  LLMs (GPT, Claude, Gemini)

 Roles:
  AI/ML Engineer
  Data Scientist
  GenAI Prompt Engineer
  AI Product Manager

2. Cybersecurity

 Technologies/Skills to Learn:
  Network Security, Firewalls (e.g., Palo Alto, Fortinet)
  SIEM tools (Splunk, ELK, QRadar)
  Identity & Access Management (IAM, Okta)
  Zero Trust Security Model
  Cloud Security (AWS Security Hub, Azure Defender)
  Ethical Hacking, Penetration Testing

 Roles:
  Security Analyst
  Cybersecurity Engineer
  SOC Analyst
  Cloud Security Architect

3. Cloud Computing & DevOps

 Technologies/Skills to Learn:
  Cloud Platforms: AWS, Azure, GCP
  Docker, Kubernetes, Helm
  Terraform, Pulumi (Infrastructure as Code)
  Jenkins, GitHub Actions, ArgoCD (CI/CD)
  Monitoring: Prometheus, Grafana, ELK
  Linux, Bash, YAML

 Roles:
  Cloud Engineer / Architect
  DevOps Engineer
  Site Reliability Engineer (SRE)
  Platform Engineer

4. Data Engineering & nalytics

 Technologies/Skills to Learn:
  SQL, Python (Pandas, NumPy)
  Apache Spark, Apache Kafka
  Snowflake, BigQuery, Redshift
  Airflow, dbt (Data Orchestration)
  Power BI, Tableau, Looker
  Data Lake, Delta Lake, Data Warehousing

 Roles:
  Data Engineer
  BI Analyst
  DataOps Engineer
  Analytics Engineer

5. Full Stack Development & App Engineering

 Technologies/Skills to Learn:
  Frontend: React.js, Next.js, Angular
  Backend: Node.js, Spring Boot, Django
  REST & GraphQL APIs
  JavaScript, TypeScript, Java, Python
  CI/CD, Docker, Testing frameworks (Jest, JUnit)
  Databases: PostgreSQL, MongoDB, Redis

 Roles:
  Full Stack Developer
  Frontend Developer
  Backend Developer
  App Developer
  Technical Lead
